item.title: Active mums 'have active children'
item.description: There is a direct link between how physically active mothers are and how active their young children are, suggests a UK study.

item.title: Police incompetent, says acid victim
item.description: A woman left scarred when he friend attacked her with acid accuses Scotland Yard of incompetence, saying they initially claimed she had done it to herself.

item.title: Rain could increase river pollution
item.description: Wetter winters in the future could increase agricultural pollution in Britain's rivers, say scientists.

item.title: Russian troops 'overrun Crimea base'
item.description: Russian troops seize control of a Crimean naval base at Feodosia, the third such attack in 48 hours, Ukrainian officials tell the BBC.

item.title: Missing plane: China spots 'objects'
item.description: A Chinese plane spots possible debris hours after it joined the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane in the southern Indian Ocean.

item.title: Taiwan students storm government HQ
item.description: Dozens hurt as Taiwan police disperse students who had occupied government headquarters to protest at a trade deal with China.

item.title: Ex-Army chief calls for more troops
item.description: The UK needs 3,000 extra troops to show it "takes its defence responsibilities seriously" in light of the Ukraine crisis, says a former head of the Army.

item.title: Rising death toll from US landslide
item.description: Rescuers searching the area of Saturday's massive mudslide in the US state of Washington find eight bodies, with a number of people still missing.

item.title: Banners to line Crow funeral route
item.description: Hundreds of trade unionists are expected to join the funeral procession of Rail, Maritime and Transport union leader Bob Crow.

item.title: Fraud 'costing NHS £5bn a year'
item.description: Fraud is costing the NHS £5bn a year, with a further £2bn lost to financial errors, the former head of its anti-fraud section tells BBC Panorama.

item.title: VIDEO: Deadly landslide in Washington state
item.description: At least eight people have been killed and several badly injured in a huge landslide in a rural area of the north-western American state of Washington, officials say.

item.title: Japan PM Abe visits Ann Frank museum
item.description: Japan's Shinzo Abe visits Amsterdam's Anne Frank House museum, weeks after 300 copies of her famous diary were vandalised in Tokyo.

item.title: Ceremony honours 'The Great Escape'
item.description: A ceremony to commemorate the Great Escape, the famous breakout from German prisoner of war camp Stalag Luft III in 1944, is due to take place later.

item.title: VIDEO: Mexico's mariachi academy run by American
item.description: Mexico's first mariachi academy plans global domination

item.title: Elton John: On the Yellow Brick Road
item.description: The story of Goodbye Yellow Brick Road by the people who made it

item.title: Did Hyman Minsky find the secret behind financial crashes?
item.description: Did this man find the secret behind financial crashes?

item.title: Cows connected to web to boost milk
item.description: Scottish dairy famers are connecting their cows to the internet to help track the animal's health and improve their milk yield.

item.title: Scots constitution to be published
item.description: An interim written Scottish constitution will be published this summer, the country's deputy first minister announces.

item.title: New tool to help catch child abusers
item.description: Victims of child sexual abuse could soon be identified more quickly, thanks to law enforcement agency work on a cloud-based archive of abuse material.

item.title: Apollo collapse due to 'old' materials
item.description: A ceiling collapse at London's Apollo Theatre has been put down to weak and old materials, the BBC has learned.

item.title: Boy, 15, charged with girl's murder
item.description: A teenage boy is charged with murdering 15-year-old Shereka Fab-Ann Marsh, who was shot in the neck in Hackney, east London.

item.title: Stamps honour 10 greats born in 1914
item.description: Actor Sir Alec Guinness and poet Dylan Thomas are among 10 "remarkable" people - all born in 1914- who feature on a new set of stamps.

item.title: VIDEO: Five ways Crimea is becoming Russian
item.description: Five ways Crimea will change as it becomes part of Russia

item.title: Johnnie Boden's passion for fashion
item.description: How Johnnie Boden came to dress the UK's yummy mummies

item.title: Fathers 'not taking paternity leave'
item.description: "Ingrained" attitudes among employers and fears about the loss of salary is preventing many men from taking paternity leave, a report has suggested.

item.title: Russian UK tourist spending dives
item.description: The UK's hotels and shops sees income from Russians fall 17% last month as visitor numbers fell back amid political unrest in Ukraine, says a report.

item.title: New push for energy firm probe
item.description: The consumer group Which? and the Federation of Small Businesses are asking regulators to investigate the "broken" energy market.

item.title: Russia invasion fears and NHS fraud - front pages
item.description: Tensions between Russia and the international community, NHS fraud claims and Samantha Cameron's onesie make headlines.

item.title: US actor James Rebhorn dies aged 65
item.description: US character actor James Rebhorn, whose most recent role was in TV series Homeland, dies at the age of 65 after a long battle with skin cancer.

item.title: Poll gains for French National Front
item.description: France's far-right anti-immigration National Front party has made significant gains in local elections, according to early results and projections.

item.title: Real Madrid 3-4 Barcelona
item.description: Lionel Messi's hat-trick helps Barcelona beat 10-man Real Madrid in a thrilling match to boost their La Liga title hopes.

item.title: Afghanistan's first spaceman returns home
item.description: From heroic spaceman to humble accountant

item.title: Venezuela probes protest abuses
item.description: Venezuela's attorney general, Luiza Ortega Diaz, says 60 cases of alleged human rights abuses during recent street protests are being investigated.

item.title: Turkey downs Syrian military jet
item.description: Turkey shoots down a Syrian military jet it says violated its airspace, but Damascus condemns what it calls "blatant aggression".

item.title: Player arrested over taxi damage
item.description: Former Newcastle United footballer Nile Ranger is arrested on suspicion of causing criminal damage to a taxi in Liverpool.

item.title: Murray eases past Lopez in Miami
item.description: Britain's Andy Murray beats Spaniard Feliciano Lopez in straight sets to reach the last 16 at the Sony Open in Miami.

item.title: Deadly Ebola reaches Guinea capital
item.description: An outbreak of the Ebola virus - which has already killed 59 people in Guinea - has reached the capital Conakry, the UN's children agency warns.

item.title: Where now for Wenger and Arsenal?
item.description: Where does Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger go now after his 1,000th game in charge of the Gunners turned into a nightmare?

item.title: Three arrested over city sex attack
item.description: Three men are arrested following a serious sexual assault on a woman in north Belfast.

item.title: Broad fined for umpire criticism
item.description: England captain Stuart Broad is fined for questioning the umpires' decision to play on in a storm at the World Twenty20.

item.title: Dewani 'to be extradited on 7 April'
item.description: A man accused of arranging the murder of his wife on their honeymoon will be extradited to South Africa on 7 April, the government there says.

item.title: Tottenham Hotspur 3-2 Southampton
item.description: Gylfi Sigurdsson comes off the bench to score a late winner for Tottenham against Southampton at White Hart Lane.

item.title: VIDEO: Kinnock name 'not always an advantage'
item.description: Stephen Kinnock, son of the former Labour leader Neil Kinnock, has been selected as the Labour candidate for Aberavon at the 2015 general election but says his family name does not necessarily work to his advantage.

item.title: Police probe 'tragic' toddler death
item.description: Police are investigating the "unexplained" death of a two-year-old boy after being called to what was described as a "serious incident" at a house.

item.title: Four killed in Kenya church attack
item.description: Four people are killed and a number are injured when gunmen open fire in a church near the Kenyan city of Mombasa, officials say.

item.title: NHS criticisms 'worry for patients'
item.description: A nurses' leader says constant criticism of care in the NHS is "worrying for patients" and unfair to staff if claims are not investigated and substantiated.

item.title: VIDEO: Bez on his plan to stand as MP
item.description: Mark Berry, better known as Bez from Manchester band Happy Mondays, is planning to stand for parliament.

item.title: Blackrock outlines Yes vote 'risks'
item.description: The world's biggest investment fund manager says Scottish independence would bring "major uncertainties, costs and risks," for Scotland and the rest of the UK.

item.title: VIDEO: Obamas visit Great Wall of China
item.description: US First Lady Michelle Obama and her daughters visit the Great Wall of China on the fourth day of their week-long visit to the country.

item.title: Man charged in river murder inquiry
item.description: A 28-year-old man is charged with murder after the body of a 45-year-old man was discovered partially submerged in a Cardiff river.
